review.title: Expert-Guided Subgroup Discovery: Methodology and Application
review.abstract: This paper presents an approach to expert-guided subgroup discovery. The main step of the subgroup discovery process, the induction of subgroup descriptions, is performed by a heuristic beam search algorithm, using a novel parametrized definition of rule quality which is analyzed in detail. The other important steps of the proposed subgroup discovery process are the detection of statistically significant properties of selected subgroups and subgroup visualization: statistically significant properties are used to enrich the descriptions of induced subgroups, while the visualization shows subgroup properties in the form of distributions of the numbers of examples in the subgroups. The approach is illustrated by the results obtained for a medical problem of early detection of patient risk groups.

sections.heading: 1. Introdu tion
sections.text: This paper deals with the problem of subgroup analysis, which goes as far as possible and has the most unusual statistical (distribution) examples for expert groups dealing with property of interest (Kl osgen, 1996; Wrobel, 1997, 2001).Its main contribution is a new methodology that supports the existence of expert examples for expert subgroups. In particular, we present a novel parameterized definition of rule quality used in a heuristi beam sear h algorithm, a rule subset algorithm for collecting sample weights, the deduction of statistical subgroups and the deduction of subgroups for selective subgroups, and a novel subgroup visualization method.

sections.heading: 2. Subgroup Dis overy: Rule Indu tion and Sele tion
sections.text: This sen tion des ribes comprises the two main steps of the entire subgroup disovery pro ess: the indu tion and the selection of interesting subgroups. These two steps as well as the entire riptive indu tion pro ess require the active participation of experts.

sections.text: The task of the subject-led subgroup is only slightly differentiated in this paper from the task of the subgroup addressed in Se tion 1 and proposed by (Kl osgen, 1996; Wrobel, 1997).Instead of defining an optimal metric for the automated subgroup, the objective here is to assist the expert in the implementation of exible and e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e e a wide range of optimal solutions. sections.heading: 3.5 Subgroup Interpretation through Visualization
sections.text: The visualization of the subgroups is very valuable for the expert interpretation of the results of the subgroups. Figures 6 and 7 show that there are no significant differences in age between CCD patients and healthy subgroups, but that CCD risk groups typically cannot be solved by looking at individual characteristics. Figure 8 illustrates the appropriateness of the recommended values, although it is known that total cholesterol is an important risk for CCD. This observation shows that the problem of CCD risk group identification cannot typically be solved by looking at individual characteristics and shows the appropriateness of the recommended approach to generating subgroup descriptions, which are a few related characteristics. Figure 10 is also interesting because it differs greatly from other characteristics.

sections.heading: 3.6 Subgroup Evaluation
sections.text: In order to evaluate the supernumerary risk groups, the medical expert tested the supernumerary subgroup patterns on an independent group of 70 people (50 CCD patients and 20 non-CCD patients from the same hospital), and the results for these patients summarized in Table 4 show that the patterns are meaningful when examining CCD patients. Approximately 90% of CCD patients were inserted into at least one of the v-patterns, and the sensitivity values (TPr) for the A1, B2, and C1 patterns are significantly higher than those used for the subgroup density in the group of patients. In the other two patterns, the values show no significant differences. Note that despite the relatively high false positive rate (FPr), the a ura y values are relatively high: a lower FPr value was achieved by selecting lower values of the generalization parameter g at the expense of the subgroups with lower superpositives.

sections.text: This analysis provides information and links to related work in subgroups, metrics of interest, evaluation yardsticks and visualizations.

sections.heading: 5.4 Subgroup Visualization
sections.text: Data visualization methods have been part of statistics and data analysis for many years and focus primarily on the representation of one or more independent variables against a dependent variable in support of exploratory data analysis (Tukey, 1977; Lee, Ong, & Quek, 1995; Unwin, 2000).However, the visualization of analysis results has only regained some attention with the spread of data mining (Card, Ma kinlay, & Shneidermann, 1999; Fayyad, Grinstein, & Wierse, 2002; Keim & Kriegel, 1996; Simo, Noirhomme-Fraiture, & Boehlen, 2001).The visualization of analysis results serves primarily four purposes: to better visualize the pattern for the end user, enabling the omparation of patterns to reactivate patterns, and enabling pattern processing and support for what-if questions. "The interest in visualization of analysis results has been fueled by the often overwhelming number of paper groups evoked by these lava groups and others.

sections.heading: 6. Con lusions
sections.text: The discussion and empirical results indicate the importance of expert-led subgroup formation within the framework of the rule quality measure that ensures compliance with high-quality rules even in the heuristic subgroup. The paper argues that the inclusion of experts in the subgroup formation is essential for effective knowledge generation. The suggested, expert-led subgroup is measured according to the following steps: problem understanding, data understanding and preparation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation, subgroup formation,
